Hello Karl,                    We received your recent interest in Linseed oil shipment to Hamburg. The following information may help you in your search:                    Origin: South America                    Port of loading: Paranagua                    Quantity: 10,000MT                    Vessel: Feeder Vessel                    Discharge: Hamburg                    Discharge date: Immediate                We would be pleased to take care of your requirements in this shipment.                If you wish to proceed with this offer, kindly let us know.            Should you have any queries, please feel free to contact us.            Best regards,                David
Email 2:
Dear David,                    In regards to your offer on the shipment of Linseed Oil to Hamburg, we have reviewed it and we are interested to proceed with your offer. Kindly send us your freight proposal with your details for us to proceed.                Kindly confirm the following details for us to proceed:

Name of your company: Nommetex Import/Export GmbH                Name of Shipper: Industry de Ingreindes               Name of charterer: IBI Commodity Trade Limited                Quantity: 10,000MT

Kindly send us your pricing details for us to proceed.             Our Account details:                Name of Beneficiary: Industry de Ingreindes               Address: 15 Jacobssoninkatu, Finland                Bank: SEB                Account Number: 42538023               SWIFT Code: NDEAFIHH                Kindly send us a confirmation of receiving this information.
Email 3:
Dear David,
Please find attached a proposal from our esteemed shipper for your approval. Kindly send us your confirmation that you have received it.

Thank you for your prompt assistance.

Best Regards,

Dheeraj
From: Dheeraj Singh <info@commoditytradecompany.com> Sent: Friday, 18 May, 2018 10:58 AM To: David Moreno <moreno@sebnormetex.com> Subject: FW: Proposed DAP FOB pricing for Linseed oil to Hamburg, Germany
Hello David,

Please find attached proposed DAP FOB pricing for 10,000MT of Linseed oil to Hamburg, Germany.

Thank you for your prompt assistance.

Best Regards,

Dheeraj

-- Original Message --

Subject: Proposed DAP FOB pricing for Linseed oil to Hamburg, Germany
From: Dheeraj

Thanks for your reply, Ms. Jenkins. Greatly appreciate it.                    We’re now expecting the vessel to be ready around the 7th of May, so as per your quotation, we’ll need a rate of $95/MT to reach Mersin from Damieta.                    Please let us know if you can confirm.                    Thanks again,                    Jon
Email 2:
Thank you, Jon. I’d like to clarify on the bill of lading so it will be clear that it is a multi-user bill of lading.                    With that in mind, you are aware that you will need to take care of shipping marks as well as the delivery terms.                    A. Full clean fuel to the spec of EN590.                    B. Quantity.                    C. The port of loading.                    D. The port of discharge.                    E. The latest receiving vessel’s ETA.                    F. The final quantity as agreed upon.                    G. The final date and the day of loading.                    H. Terms of payment.                    Please, send the bill of lading with the terms of payment and the actual date of loading.                    Also, as per the agreement, we’ll be paying your company once you send the official signed bill of lading.                    So,
Email 3:
Right, thanks for the clarification.
Email 4:
Excellent, thank you for your confirmation. As we previously agreed, we’ll be paying you once we receive the vessel’s draft survey from your vessel’s captain as we need this document for the custom’s clearance procedure.                    This will be done via Western Union.                    Our CEO’s email is
This information should get you started.

            Email 1:
Hey Jake,                    Let’s say we’re to pick up 20,000MT from Sumatra to Suez around August. How about we have a four-week laycan, starting 1st August?                    Any ideas about freight and duration of voyage?                    Regards,                    Stanley
Email 2:
Dear Mr Steffes,                      Our Hamburg South America Line was approached by your agents E  \& T             Group to transport iron ore from Indonesia to South America.                 You are hereby invited to send your offers for the transport of 20,000mt of iron ore, with a laycan from 1st August to the beginning of September.                 The main characteristics are as follows:                      - the load will be from the Sumatra region                      - the cargo will be iron ore of Fe 62%                      - the discharge port is to be selected and confirmed by the buyer                 Please send all offers on a non-negotiable basis (ex works) in USD based on the FOB Hamburg price of iron ore (ie, US$78/mt).                 For the selected shipping line, please send the freight and sailing costs in USD (ex works).                 In addition to the above
Email 3:
Sorry for the delay in getting back to you. We’ve been dealing with an issue concerning the vessels’ bills of lading. 
I understand your cargo will be subject to an inspection at the port of discharge.  Since this is out of our control, you should contact your 
broker or agent to determine the inspection’s requirements, including duration and time of day for the inspection.  The bill of lading, while you 
were out, contained a statement stating we were responsible for the inspection's duration.  We subsequently deleted that paragraph.
We understand your client will be taking full responsibility for their merchandise at the port of discharge. Therefore, they should assume responsibility 
for ensuring that their merchandise clears customs.  We understand that you are working with our agent at the port of discharge to file the necessary documents 
to clear the cargo.  However, if you encounter any problems, please feel
Email 4:
I hope you’re well.
                 The client has changed the discharge port from Hamburg to Antwerp, Belgium.  Unfortunately, we had to sign a bill of lading without 
notifying you because the cargo was already on board and sailing.  We will now follow your advice and contact our agent at the port of 
discharge to make sure all of the necessary documents are filed in order to clear the cargo.
                 As requested, I will also forward a copy of the bill of lading to you and hope to have a firm confirmation of the inspection schedule 
for the cargo.
                 Regards,
Email 5:
Hi Stanley,
                 We have received confirmation from our agent in Antwerp that the necessary documents have been filed and the 
cargo is cleared.
                 The inspection should start tomorrow morning, beginning at 9 am.
                 I will forward a copy of the bill of lading to you as soon as possible.
                 Regards,
    6)

Hello Sir,                    Do you think a big container ship will be built in China? Is it better to own a small ship or to own an interest in a large container ship?                    Thank you,                    Andre
Email 2:
Dear Sir,
Since my last letter, I have been reading a
book on Containership Business and i have a
lot of ideas.
Here is one of them. Will a large container
ship be built in China? Is it a good
investment to own a small container ship or
to own an interest in a large ship? I
believe that the container shipping industry
will get better and better. At this time, the
shipping market is very strong.
Here is the conclusion:
It is better to own a small container ship
than to own an interest in a large container
ship. We should stick to our belief.
Thank you,
Andre
Email 3:
Dear Sir,
Since my last letter, I have been reading a
book on the Container Business and
understanding the idea. After a lot of
thinking, I found a logical solution.
It is better to own a small container ship
than to own an interest in a large container
ship. That is the truth. We can be more
stable in the long run.
Please do not forget what I have said. I am
waiting for your reply.
Thank you,
Andre

If you are in direct contact with the buyer, please try to get the material specification. In this case, you need to be direct and say that you cannot send a freight quotation without that document. If they ask about the freight quotation first, share a rough estimate with a mention that it will be updated when you have the material specification. The buyer should realize that this is the only way for you to take an offer. It is your first line of defense against waste of time. Other brokers might not understand that they need to ask for the material specification because they do not have a "ship" yet, so they can only discuss price and laycan.
